awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--A Model/Proxy Synthesis of Walker Circulation Trends During the Last Millennium
awd_abstract_narration:
The Pacific Walker circulation alters weather and climate extremes around the world, but its sensitivity to external climate forcings remains unknown.  In particular,  observational estimates of 20th century trends in the Walker circulation provide conflicting results, with some suggesting a strengthening and others a weakening or no trend, complicating the attribution of these trends to any specific forcing. 

Paleoclimate records can improve the detection and attribution of trends by providing longer-term context, but their use has been hindered by the lack of multi-proxy synthesis products and climate model simulations covering the last millennium.  This project aims to create new quantitative reconstructions of multiple Walker circulation metrics using the recently constructed PAGES Iso2k database, and to evaluate the mechanisms for variability and trends in these metrics using the Community Earth System Model Last Millennium Ensemble (LME) and new simulations with its isotope-enabled complement (iLME). The research seeks to apply these new tools to answer one central question: What are the mechanisms underlying Walker circulation variability and trends from the Last Millennium through the 20th century, and what are the relative roles of external forcings and internal variability?

The potential Broader Impacts (B.I.) includes strong science and educational aspects. Climate variability in the tropical Pacific affects societies and ecosystems; understanding long-term variability of the Walker circulation is thus critical for improving projections of the impacts of 21st century climate change.  This scientifically-interdisciplinary research team is composed entirely of early-career researchers, two of whom are female.  The project will support a graduate student and postdoctoral researcher. High school students from underrepresented demographics will be recruited for summer internships and mentoring through a program that targets diversity in STEM. Finally, the project will produce multi-proxy synthesis reconstructions of tropical Pacific climate variability and iLME ensemble members, all of which will be made available as resources to the wider scientific and civil communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Pacific Walker Circulation, or PWC, is a pattern of atmospheric circulation along the equator that spans the Pacific Ocean. The strength of the PWC affects weather patterns around the world, in addition to driving changes in ocean circulation such as El Nino and La Nina events. Understanding how climate change will affect the PWC is therefore extremely important in order to better assess its future impacts. However, model projections of future PWC changes disagree with one another, and observational data are highly uncertain before the mid-20th century, meaning that we don't have good estimates of long-term trends in the real-world PWC. This project was designed to improve our understanding of past Walker circulation variations from both the modeling and observational perspectives.
New climate model simulations including the ability to directly simulate the stable isotopes of water (so-called "isotope-enabled" simulations) were performed, spanning the last millennium. These were combined with new reconstructions of past climate, created using a new database of paleoclimate information called Iso2k, also developed under this project. Iso2k is based on the stable isotopes of water in different natural archives such as corals, tree rings, sediment and ice cores. Together, we find that there has been little influence of human activity on the PWC so far, largely because the impact of greenhouse gas emissions has been damped by the emission of air pollutants (so-called "anthropogenic aerosol" emissions). However, by using water isotopes to identify patterns associated with individual external influences on climate, we may eventually be able to improve models' representation of responses to climate change.
This project also supported a postdoctoral researcher and a graduate student, who participated in several educational activities. The student received training in the science of water isotopes and paleoclimate through attendance at IsoCamp and the Urbino Summer School in Paleoclimatology. The entire project team also conceived and ran a day-long workshop on climate change and its effects on Hawaii for the "Ep'IK" summer school program for high school students in Honolulu.
